Article.Abstract: Treatment-resistant Lyme arthritis, which may result from infection-induced autoimmunity, is associated with reactivity to a T cell epitope of outer-surface protein A (OspA(161-175)) of Borrelia burgdorferi sensu stricto (Bb). This syndrome has been noted primarily in the United States where only Bb is present, and rarely in Europe where Borrelia garinii (Bg) and Borrelia afzelii (Ba) predominate. To gain a better understanding of this epitope, we identified its species-specific polymorphisms, determined their immunogenicity, and characterized the contribution of individual amino acids. Based on published sequences the Bb peptide differed from the Ba peptide in six of the nine core residues (amino acids 165-173), whereas the Bg peptide usually differed in three of the nine residues. Lymphocytes from seven patients with treatment-resistant Lyme arthritis proliferated in response to the Bb peptide, but not to the Ba or Bg peptide. Substitution analysis showed that valine166 and threonine172 were critical for the immunogenicity of the Bb peptide. Thus, consistent with the geographic distribution of the illness, the European causative agents of Lyme borreliosis usually lack the putative pathogenic OspA epitope. These observations are consistent with the hypothesis that T cell recognition of this epitope is important in the induction of autoimmunity in treatment-resistant Lyme arthritis.
Article.ArticleTitle: Molecular characterization of the OspA(161-175) T cell epitope associated with treatment-resistant Lyme arthritis: differences among the three pathogenic species of Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Utilizing substitution analysis within the OspA epitopic region of Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg) (non-arthritogenic species of the pathogenic spirochete B. burgdorferi sensu lato), T-cell responses were measured and the authors have identified V166 and T172 as critical in immunogenicity of the Borrelia burdorferi (Bb) OspA epitope. The shortest truncation giving a full proliferative response reported in this study was 164 SYVLEGTLTAE 174.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Comparisons were made of T-cell proliferation in response to various truncations and a Y165G substitution. Only the Y165G substitution had a significant effect on proliferation. All truncations of Bb peptide were comparable to wild-type responses.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation was quite robust in response to all tested concentrations of the Bb peptide. These results were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg), which did not elicit a strong response.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Synovial fluid mononuclear cells (SFMCs) were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cell proliferation was well above background levels.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cell proliferation was well above background levels.

Cell proliferation was above background. SFMC (synovial fluid mononuclear cells) from two patients and PBMCs from one patient were tested. This assay confirmed the computer prediction that the OspA epitope is DRB1*0401 restricted.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation showed a direct correlation to cytokine production. These results were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg), which elicited only weak or no proliferative and cytokine release reponses.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation showed a direct correlation with cytokine production. Results with epitope were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg), which elicited only weak or no proliferative responses and cytokine release.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Utilizing substitution analysis within the OspA epitopic region of Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg) (non-arthritogenic species of the pathogenic spirochete B. burgdorferi sensu lato), T-cell responses were measured and the authors have identified V166 and T172 within the core sequence as critical in immunogenicity of the Borrelia burdorferi (Bb) OspA epitope, which are absent in this epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation showed a direct correlation with cytokine production. Results with epitope were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb) and Borrelia garinii (Bg).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: This assay compared the response of T-cells to epitope with repsonses to homologous epitopes from Borrelia burgdoreri (Bb) and Borrelia garinii (Bg). T-cell proliferation was weak in response to all tested concentrations of Ba peptide.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation showed a direct correlation with cytokine production. Results with epitope were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb) and Borrelia garinii (Bg).

Cell proliferation was at or just above background in response to Ba epitope. SFMC (synovial fluid mononuclear cells) from four patients and PBMCs from three patients were tested. PBMCs and SFMCs contained either homozygous HLA II DRB1*010 or HLA II DRB1*040, or were heterozygous for both alleles.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Utilizing substitution analysis within the OspA epitopic region of Borrelia afzelii (Ba) and Borrelia garinii (Bg) (non-arthritogenic species of the pathogenic spirochete B. burgdorferi sensu lato), T-cell responses were measured and the authors have identified V166 and T172 within the core sequence as critical in immunogenicity of the Borrelia burdorferi (Bb) OspA epitope, which are absent in this epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Very little proliferation or cytokine release was observed. Results with epitope were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb) and Borrelia afzelii (Ba).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Very little proliferation or cytokine release was observed. Results with epitope were compared to homologous epitopes from Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb) and Borrelia afzelii (Ba).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMCs were restimulated for five days prior to proliferation assay.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: T-cell proliferation was weak in response to all tested concentrations of Bg peptide.

Cell proliferation was above background. SFMC (synovial fluid mononuclear cells) from four patients and PBMCs from three patients were tested. SFMCs and PBMCs were either homozygous for HLA II DRB1*0401 or HLA II DRB1*0101, or heterozygous for both.
